footer.socialMediaText: We deleted our accounts because we saw firsthand what happens to nature when stunning locations get overcrowded due to popularity on instagram. We are shocked and sad and cannot quite understand why (some) people behave in certain ways and think it is ok to do what they do to nature. We cannot imagine people behaving this way in their own backyard - so why on earth would you behave like this in public? Campers are destroying their own way of life and we can understand why locals get fed up even in countries where wild camping is tolerated/accepted.
footer.socialMediaQuote: Leave nothing but footsteps; take nothing but memories!

about.title: We are Kathrin & Stefan
about.imageAlt: Kathrin and Stefan during their trip to Banff, Canada
about.paragraph1: Ever since we met we discovered that we share the same passion for traveling and discovering nature and foreign cultures. We love to hike and anything that ups the adrenalin levels. After one of our first multi day hikes (West Highland Way) we started toying with the idea to get our own van. We decided to stress test that type of traveling with a 4 week camping trip through Canada.
about.paragraph2: It blew our minds and we discovered that we love this mode of traveling. The freedom is just incredible and that is exactly what we are looking for.
about.paragraph3: So, in 2024 we finally got our van Wilma and are now getting ready for the great escape ‚Ä¶ err‚Ä¶ adventure!

aboutUs.title: This is us
aboutUs.headline: Two storytellers. One rolling home.
aboutUs.heroImageAlt: Stefan and Kathrin on a mountain top overlooking Jasper, Canada

intro.paragraph1: Hi, we're Stefan and Kathrin, an adventurous couple from Germany with a shared passion for traveling, hiking, and immersing ourselves in nature. Our curiosity drives us to explore the world, and right now, we're on an exciting journey across Europe in our campervan Wilma.
intro.paragraph2: By living on the road, we've embraced the freedom to wander wherever the wind takes us‚Äîwithout the need to rely on hotels or flights. We're constantly discovering hidden gems, breathtaking landscapes, and unforgettable experiences, all while living life at our own pace.

kathrin.title: Kathrin
kathrin.imageAlt: Kathrin on a riverbank in Canada
kathrin.paragraph1: I grew up surrounded by the peaceful countryside near Bergisch Gladbach, but life's adventure took me to various cities‚ÄîCologne, London, Berlin‚Äîand eventually, back to the quiet charm of rural living. While I love the buzz and excitement of cities, I'm definitely a country soul at heart. There's nothing like the feeling of being surrounded by nature. Whether I'm hiking through forests, cycling along winding trails, surfing the waves, or climbing to new heights, I'm happiest when I'm outdoors, breathing in the fresh air and pushing my limits.
kathrin.paragraph2: When I'm not out adventuring, you'll find me unwinding in more creative ways. Drawing, crafting, and cooking are my go-to activities to slow down and relax, finding joy in creating something with my hands. And of course, I'm all about sports‚Äînothing beats the thrill of a good challenge.
kathrin.paragraph3: My biggest dream? To explore the world with my partner, discovering new places, soaking up different cultures, and meeting amazing people along the way. The best part of the journey is sharing those experiences with others‚Äîand I can't wait to see where the road leads!

stefan.title: Stefan
stefan.imageAlt: Stefan standing on a mountain top in Banff, Canada
stefan.paragraph1: I grew up in Germany in an area called "Niederrhein" (lower Rhine area) which is really really flat. From my teenage days I was drawn towards technology. I loved tinkering around with computers and later worked as a projectionist in the local cinema to earn some money while going to school.
stefan.paragraph2: To this day anything tech excites me, but I also really love the great outdoors. The more mountaneous the better, I guess this stems from having grown up without anything remotely hilly close by.
stefan.paragraph3: Despite having lived in really busy cities (Cologne, London, Berlin) and having loved the experience, I feel like I am done with big crowds of people and nowadays mostly enjoy the quiet of a remote area. Give me a comfy chair by a cozy fire in the middle of nowehere, a blanket on the beach or a cliff to dangle my feet off of and you will see me smiling :)
stefan.paragraph4: As a hobby I love to dabble in photography. I have tried people photography back when we lived in London and have since pivoted to landscape and travel photography.

friendsAndPartners.title: Friends & Partners
friendsAndPartners.heroImageAlt: Sunset over the ocean in Canada
friendsAndPartners.intro: Over time we have met some amazing people and companies that share our passion for sustainable travel and van life. Here are some of our friends and partners that we can wholeheartedly recommend.

partners.name: L2 Print Factory
partners.description: L2 Print Factory is run by Lea and Leon, two professional engineers specializing in building technology. They identified a need for professional 3D printing services and started their own business ‚Äì L2 Print Factory. In their private lives, they are passionate travelers and also own a camper. So it was only natural for them to offer high-quality solutions for the camping sector. They have printed custom solutions for us, from specialized flanges to decorative items. Simply brilliant!

partners.name: trackiwi
partners.description: trackiwi is a GPS tracker designed specifically for campers, and there's one reason it really stands out to us: privacy is at the core. The device stores our routes indefinitely, automatically detects overnight spots, and even includes a built-in alarm system. We've spoken with Fabian, the founder, multiple times and we're absolutely convinced ‚Äì not just by the product, but by how he listens to community feedback and constantly delivers new features. A truly great company with an awesome product!

background.title: Background
background.intro: Our goal is to be as sustainable and environmentally responsible as possible. For us "leave no trace" also includes trying to keep our waste water as organic as possible. This is for two reasons:
background.reason1: We just don't like chemicals in general and we want to avoid getting in touch with chemicals in general.
background.reason2: We want to be as independent as possible and part of that means trying to be able to get rid of our wastewater (grey water) anywhere without needing a special dumpstation.
background.closing: So, we are looking for organic products for every aspect of daily life and we want to introduce you to the products we are using to make sure we are as sustainable as possible. All the products are tested thoroughly by us or we have been using them for a long time already.

bathroom.title: Bathroom
bathroom.duschbrocken: Shower soap & shampoo: We have been using the products from Duschbrocken for a very long time, even from before we started camping and they are just fantastic products.

sections.whatYouNeedToKnow: What you need to know about {country}

norway.name: Norway
norway.heroImageAlt: View of the aurora borealis above the village of Reine in Lofoten, Norway

freeCamping.title: Free Camping Availability
freeCamping.content: Freedom camping is officially allowed in most places as long as you follow the general rules (stay max 2 night only, 150m away from houses, respect nature, take your trash with you, etc.). In practice, this means you can find plenty of nice spots in more remote areas, but it can be tricky in popular touristic areas or close to bigger cities. Overall though, we had no issues finding great free spots.

paidCampsites.title: Paid Campsites
paidCampsites.content: There are plenty of paid campsites available, especially in touristic areas. Prices vary depending on the location and facilities offered, but generally range from 20‚Ç¨ to 40‚Ç¨ per night for a motorhome pitch.

infrastructure.title: Motorhome Infrastructure
infrastructure.content: Norway has a well-developed motorhome infrastructure with many dedicated parking areas, service stations, and dump points for waste disposal. You can find these facilities in most towns and along major routes.

mobileInternet.title: Mobile Internet Quality
mobileInternet.content: Mobile internet coverage is generally good throughout Norway, especially along the main roads and in urban areas. However, in more remote regions, such as the fjords and mountainous areas, coverage can be spotty or non-existent although this was extremely rare in our experience.

simCard.title: SIM Card Access
simCard.content: You can find them pretty much at every corner.

wifi.title: Wi-Fi Availability
wifi.content: Wi-Fi is widely available in cafes, restaurants, and campsites. Many public libraries and tourist information centers also offer free Wi-Fi access.

groceries.title: Groceries & Dining Out
groceries.content: Groceries are generally more expensive than in other European countries, especially for imported goods. Dining out can also be pricey, with a meal at a mid-range restaurant costing around 25‚Ç¨ to 40‚Ç¨ per person.

fuel.title: Fuel Prices
fuel.content: Fuel prices in Norway are among the highest in Europe, with petrol and diesel prices often exceeding 2‚Ç¨ per liter. It's advisable to budget accordingly for fuel costs, especially if you plan to do a lot of driving.

tolls.title: Toll Roads & Vignettes
tolls.content: Norway has numerous toll roads, bridges, and tunnels. Most tolls are collected electronically, so you don't need to stop at toll booths. You can register your vehicle online to receive invoices for the tolls incurred during your stay. autoPASS is the system used for toll collection in Norway.

borders.title: Border Crossings
borders.content: Norway is part of the Schengen Area, so there are generally no border checks when entering from other Schengen countries. However, if you're coming from a non-Schengen country, be prepared for possible passport checks and customs inspections.

police.title: Police Attitude & Checks
police.content: We did not have any experience with the police.

water.title: Water Access
water.content: Tap water in Norway is of excellent quality and safe to drink. You can refill your water tanks at campsites, service stations, and public water points found in many towns and cities. Most gas stations also offer water refill services.

dumps.title: Dump Stations & Toilets
dumps.content: There are numerous dump stations available throughout Norway, often located at campsites, service areas, and some public parking areas. Public toilets can be found in towns, tourist areas, and along major roads, although they may sometimes require a small fee for use.

shopping.title: Shopping & Supplies
shopping.content: Grocery stores and supermarkets are widely available in urban areas and larger towns. In more remote areas, options may be limited, so it's advisable to stock up on supplies when you have the chance. Specialty stores for camping and outdoor gear can be found in larger cities.

laundromats.title: Laundromats
laundromats.content: Laundromats are available in larger towns and cities, as well as some campsites. Many campsites also offer laundry facilities for guests.

bestTime.title: Best Time to Visit
bestTime.content: The best time to visit Norway largely depends on your interests. For milder weather and longer days, the summer months (June to August) are ideal. If you're interested in winter activities like skiing or seeing the Northern Lights, then the winter months (December to February) are best. We were in Norway between Semptemer and November and found it to be a great time as well, although a bit rainy which might be less once temperatures are consistently below freezing.

bugs.title: Bug/Mosquito Factor
bugs.content: In general, Norway has a low mosquito population compared to other countries. However, in the summer months, especially in areas with standing water or dense vegetation, you may encounter some mosquitoes and other insects. Using insect repellent and wearing long sleeves and pants during peak mosquito activity times (dawn and dusk) can help minimize bites.

safety.title: Safety
safety.content: No concerns, we felt super safe.

attitudes.title: Local Attitudes Toward Campers
attitudes.content: Norwegians are generally very accepting of campervans and motorhomes, especially when travelers respect local regulations and the environment. The concept of 'Allemannsretten' (the right to roam) is deeply ingrained in Norwegian culture, allowing people to camp on uncultivated land for short periods. As long as you follow the guidelines for responsible camping, you should find a welcoming attitude from locals.

noise.title: Noise & Peacefulness
noise.content: Norway is known for its tranquility and peacefulness, especially in rural and remote areas. You can expect a quiet environment, particularly away from urban centers and popular tourist spots.

highlights.title: Cultural Highlights
highlights.content: Norway boasts a rich cultural heritage with numerous museums, historical sites, and festivals celebrating its Viking history, Sami culture, and maritime traditions. Don't miss the chance to explore local art galleries, traditional music performances, and culinary experiences that showcase Norwegian cuisine.

language.title: Language & Communication
language.content: Norwegian is the official language, but English is widely spoken and understood, especially in tourist areas. Most Norwegians are proficient in English, making communication relatively easy for travelers who do not speak Norwegian.

gems.title: Hidden Gems or Disappointments
gems.content: We recommend looking for spots off the beaten path. We stumbled upon a small community which is building a to-scale viking ship for instance. Of course Lofoten etc. are must-see locations, but try to look beyond those.

apps.title: Apps That Helped
apps.content: Park4Night, YR (for weather), numerous aurora forecast apps

etiquette.title: Local Etiquette
etiquette.content: Norwegians value privacy and personal space, so it's important to be respectful of these cultural norms. When interacting with locals, a polite greeting and a friendly demeanor go a long way. Additionally, when camping or parking your campervan, always seek permission if you're on private land and adhere to local regulations regarding waste disposal and noise levels.

poland.name: Poland
poland.heroImageAlt: View of Gdansk, Poland from above

freeCamping.title: Free Camping Availability
freeCamping.content: It was very easy to find free campsites. The Polish seem to enjoy camping quite a bit, too.

infrastructure.title: Motorhome Infrastructure
infrastructure.content: It was very easy to find fresh water and dumpsites.

mobileInternet.title: Mobile Internet Quality
mobileInternet.content: 4G/5G signal strength is exceptional in most places and we didn't have any issues at all.

wifi.title: Wi-Fi Availability
wifi.content: We did not pay too much attention, but noticed public Wi-Fis every now and then, even city-run networks.

groceries.title: Groceries & Dining Out
groceries.content: Groceries are a bit cheaper than in Germany, but it depends on what you buy.

fuel.title: Fuel Prices
fuel.content: Diesel is a lot cheaper than we are used to from Germany. At the time of traveling it ranged around 1.35‚Ç¨/l. LPG was ~ 0.80‚Ç¨/l

laundry.title: Laundry
laundry.content: We didn't do any laundry in Poland.

roads.title: Road Quality & Driving Conditions
roads.content: Road conditions are mostly excellent, however, there are many construction sites (to make the roads this awesome).

tolls.title: Toll Roads & Vignettes
tolls.content: There are no toll roads (at least not for <3.5t).

borders.title: Border Crossings
borders.content: Poland is part of the Schengen are, meaning no border checks when you enter from another Schengen country.

police.title: Police Attitude & Checks
police.content: We did not have any experience with the police.

water.title: Water Access
water.content: Easy to find either at official camp spots or gas stations. On highways watch out for "WC BUS" signs.

dumps.title: Dump Stations & Toilets
dumps.content: Since we only use environmentally friendly products and a dry composting toilet, it was very easy for us to find dump stations as we do not rely on those capable of handling chemical waste water. I wouldn't expect you to have any issues even with a chemical toilet though. On highways watch out for "WC BUS" signs.

shopping.title: Shopping & Supplies
shopping.content: Easily accessible, there are many supermarkets, even LIDL.

bestTime.title: Best Time to Visit
bestTime.content: I'd say pretty much all year round, it's your typical mid-European weather: wet in Winter without any real extremes,  somewhat hot yet also wet in Summer.

bugs.title: Bug/Mosquito Factor
bugs.content: When you are close to open waters you will find bugs/mosquitos, but far from Scotland levels ;)

safety.title: Safety
safety.content: No concerns, we felt super safe.

attitudes.title: Local Attitudes Toward Campers
attitudes.content: We didn't feel especially welcome nor unwelcome - our impression was that people just don't care about it. Most people are super friendly once you start having a chat.

noise.title: Noise & Peacefulness
noise.content: You can find both, however, we traveled during high season and most Polish people were on vacation themselves, so our experience is a little skewed.

language.title: Language & Communication
language.content: English will get you far in cities, outside you might run into trouble, however, we always managed to communicate somehow.

gems.title: Hidden Gems or Disappointments
gems.content: Check out the Masurian Lake District as well as the WWII museum in Gdansk!

belgium.name: Belgium
belgium.heroImageAlt: Sunset over lovely fields and meados in Oostende, Belgium

freeCamping.title: Free Camping Availability
freeCamping.content: We had little to no issues finding free sites to stay. We were very surprised to find many fellow campers who offered to stay on their grounds for free or at a (voluntary) donation.

paidCampsites.title: Paid Campsites
paidCampsites.content: You can easily find lots of paid campsites or smaller sites run by private individuals. The cost varies a lot.

infrastructure.title: Motorhome Infrastructure
infrastructure.content: It was very easy to find fresh water and dumpsites. Getting rid of trash, however, proved tricky at times.

mobileInternet.title: Mobile Internet Quality
mobileInternet.content: 4G/5G signal strength is exceptional in most places. We only broke out Starlink once and that was for its unlimited bandwidth feature, not due to connectivity issues.

simCard.title: SIM Card Access
simCard.content: You can find them pretty much at every corner.

wifi.title: Wi-Fi Availability
wifi.content: We did not pay too much attention, but noticed public Wi-Fis every now and then, even city-run networks.

groceries.title: Groceries & Dining Out
groceries.content: Groceries are quite expensive compared to the rest of Europe as is dining out. You will need some extra budget for Belgium.

fuel.title: Fuel Prices
fuel.content: Diesel - to our surprise - is slightly less expensive than we are used to from Germany. At the time of traveling it ranged around 1.50‚Ç¨/l. LPG was ~ 0.95‚Ç¨/l

laundry.title: Laundry
laundry.content: We did not have any issues finding great laundry services. We paid ‚Ç¨8 for one load of laundry and one load in the dryer.

roads.title: Road Quality & Driving Conditions
roads.content: Road conditions are mostly excellent until you enter Wallonia, you can find some very nasty roads there.

tolls.title: Toll Roads & Vignettes
tolls.content: There are no toll roads (at least not for <3.5t).

borders.title: Border Crossings
borders.content: Belgium is part of the Schengen are, meaning no border checks when you enter from another Schengen country.

police.title: Police Attitude & Checks
police.content: We did not have any experience with the police.

water.title: Water Access
water.content: Easy to find either at official camp spots or gas stations.

dumps.title: Dump Stations & Toilets
dumps.content: Since we only use environmentally friendly products and a dry composting toilet, it was very easy for us to find dump stations as we do not rely on those capable of handling chemical waste water. I wouldn't expect you to have any issues even with a chemical toilet though.

shopping.title: Shopping & Supplies
shopping.content: No issues at all here, it's Europe, you get everything everywhere any time.

laundromats.title: Laundromats
laundromats.content: Very easy to find good ones with plenty of machines.

bestTime.title: Best Time to Visit
bestTime.content: I'd say pretty much all year round, it's your typical mid-European weather: wet in Winter without any real extremes,  somewhat hot yet also wet in Summer.

bugs.title: Bug/Mosquito Factor
bugs.content: When you are close to open waters you will find bugs/mosquitos, but far from Scotland levels ;)

safety.title: Safety
safety.content: No concerns, we felt super safe.

attitudes.title: Local Attitudes Toward Campers
attitudes.content: Belgians are a great camper nation themselves, so their attitude towards campers is very welcoming. You will easily get in touch with locals. We even had someone on a bike stop for a chat - a proper chat!

noise.title: Noise & Peacefulness
noise.content: We did not have any issues, however, be aware wild camping is not allowed and it will vary from place to place. As always, leave a spot cleaner than you found it!

highlights.title: Cultural Highlights
highlights.content: Well, it's obvious isn't it? Belgian waffles and double-fried French fries with any of the many outstanding local beers! I'd personally suggest a Kwak!

language.title: Language & Communication
language.content: Belgium has three official languages: Dutch, French and German. You will find that most speak Dutch and French, German is a bit more rare. While generally English will get you around, you might run into issues in Wallonia.

gems.title: Hidden Gems or Disappointments
gems.content: Oostende and Westende host a couple of amazing events during summer time right at the beach, don't miss them!

etiquette.title: Local Etiquette
etiquette.content: No tipping in Belgium, but you would round up to the next "even" amount.

austria.heroImageAlt: View of a beautiful building in Vienna, Austria

freeCamping.content: We found it exceptionally hard to find spots. Mostly, because the spots that once existed are now prohibited due to the usual reason: Some campers ruin it for all of us. Let's all please follow the basic rules and leave spots cleaner than we found them!

paidCampsites.content: You can easily find lots of paid campsites or smaller sites run by private individuals. The cost varies a lot and in our opinion is way too high - some charge upwards of 40‚Ç¨ for a simple pitch with no services.

infrastructure.title: Motorhome Infrastructure
infrastructure.content: Also quite difficult at times and we didn't really find a "trick" we can share.

mobileInternet.content: 4G/5G signal strength is exceptional in most places.

wifi.title: Wi-Fi Availability
wifi.content: Didn't seem like there is a lot of free Wi-Fi going around.

groceries.content: Groceries and dinner are OK mostly. Some items are on the more expensive side.

roads.title: Road Quality & Driving Conditions
roads.content: Road conditions are  quite good. They should be as you pay a toll!

tolls.title: Toll Roads & Vignettes
tolls.content: Highways are toll roads and you must purchase before entering otherwise you will face steep fines. You can purchase online and it's priced ok.

borders.title: Border Crossings
borders.content: Austria is part of the Schengen are, meaning no border checks when you enter from another Schengen country.

police.title: Police Attitude & Checks
police.content: We did not have any experience with the police.

water.title: Water Access
water.content: Sometimes a bit tricky to find fresh water.

dumps.title: Dump Stations & Toilets
dumps.content: Also a bit tricky, best to plan ahead a little..

shopping.title: Shopping & Supplies
shopping.content: No issues at all here, it's Europe, you get everything everywhere any time.

laundromats.title: Laundromats
laundromats.content: Very easy to find good ones with plenty of machines.

bestTime.title: Best Time to Visit
bestTime.content: I'd say pretty much all year round, it's your typical mid-European weather: wet in Winter without any real extremes,  somewhat hot yet also wet in Summer.

bugs.title: Bug/Mosquito Factor
bugs.content: When you are close to open waters you will find bugs/mosquitos, but far from Scotland levels ;)

safety.title: Safety
safety.content: No concerns, we felt super safe.

attitudes.title: Local Attitudes Toward Campers
attitudes.content: Mixed - some areas are clearly fed up with us campers (due to our own fault of course). But some are very open and we even found a couple who run a free campsite!

noise.title: Noise & Peacefulness
noise.content: It's usually very quite once you leave bigger cities.

highlights.title: Cultural Highlights
highlights.content: Wiener Schnitzel (so we heard - we are vegetarians) and Apfelstrudel!

gems.title: Hidden Gems or Disappointments
gems.content: Biggest disappointment was the cost of camping!

canadaRoadTrip2023.title: Canada road trip 2023
canadaRoadTrip2023.heroImageAlt: View of Maligne Lake and surrounding mountains in Jasper National Park, Canada

intro.paragraph1: We hired a campervan to travel British Columbia and parts of Alberta in September and October 2023.
intro.paragraph2: After thorough research we decided to rent a smaller van (C-Small) from Fraserway RV. We were told that these weren't as run down as vans from other rental companies and that should proof to be true.
intro.paragraph3: We chose this time of year as we really wanted to see the lovely fall colours.
intro.paragraph4: However, about 4-6 weeks before the departure date news arrived about really bad forest fires and parts of our planned route were affected. It wasn't clear up until the actual date of departure whether we would be able to travel the intended route.
intro.paragraph5: While passing flying over Canada we could actually see very high smoke stacks from many forest fires and were quite worried. We did get lucky though and were able to drive the entire route. Locals, however, told us that just weeks before the areas where clouded by thick smoke and we could see huge areas of burned down trees.
intro.paragraph6: We opted for pre-booking all the campsites as we saw that they were filling up rather quickly and we had no idea how independent the campervan would be. Initially we wanted to remain as flexible as possible, but in key locations we waned to make sure we would definitely be able to visit. As a consequence we pre-booked the entire route. In the end it was more important to us to experience the locations rather than remain fully flexible. Ultimately, we could still depart a location early and switch if we didn't like it (spoiler: and we did, because holy {swearword} those Canadian cargo trains honk their horns all night and at some campsites you sleep right next to the tracks!).
intro.paragraph7: We hope you enjoy our little blog about the trip!

wilmaGas.title: Gas
wilmaGas.heroImageAlt: View of the Somar√∏y island from the hilltop.

background.title: Background
background.paragraph1: We use gas in our van for cooking, heating and warm water. As such gas is a critical resource that we don't want to run out of. Our gas compartment can hold up to two 11kg gas bottles.
background.paragraph2: In cold weather (winter) we can make 1 bottle last about 4-5 days - depending on the temperature. In summer time it's pretty much endless as we don't use the heater and cooking barely uses any gas. Warm water is only needed for a cozy shower.
background.paragraph3: During our very first winter trip we made the experience that it can be tricky to get your gas bottles filled or exchanged for full bottles.
background.paragraph4: This is especially true as we had two bottles from "Alugas" as they weigh much less than the standard steel ones. Unfortunately though, they are harder to come by even in Germany.
background.paragraph5: Another challenge is that German gas bottles don't come with the 80% shut off safety valve and thus getting them filled outside of Germany is a real challenge.
background.paragraph6: Lastly, we vacationed over Christmas and New Years when many shops are closed.
background.paragraph7: So, we figured this isn't a sustainable situation and we don't want to be limited in range by the proximity of the nearest available gas filling/exchange station!

solution.title: Solution
solution.paragraph1: Gas tank bottles ("Gastankflaschen") i.e. gas bottles that do have the 80% safety shut off valve and can be filled at any LPG/Autogas gas station.
solution.paragraph2: These bottles are extremely convenient. You can fill them at any gas station that sells LPG/Autogas and it's completely safe. Even better: you can fill them at any time, you don't have to wait for a bottle to be completely empty (like you would if you had to exchange it). That means when you come by a station with LPG/Autogas, just top up your bottle and you are pretty much never running out of gas again.
solution.paragraph3: I know many people at this point will raise their finger üëÜ and comment on T√úV and the general legal situation for gas tank bottles. I won't address this any further as there are many articles and YouTube videos about it and it is ever changing. You have to come to your own conclusion.
solution.paragraph4: The installation should be done by a certified professional as you are making changes to your gas infrastructure. Don't cheap out on sensible areas! It is usually done within a day or two and the price is well worth the reward. Since we are close (ish) to Cologne, we had our installation done by Ralf Kohl from <link>https://www.wohnmobil-elektronik.de/</link>. The service and consultation was great and the installation only took a couple of hours. Ralf also gave us a thoroguh introduction and step-by-step instructions how to use the system safely.
solution.paragraph5: We opted to change both bottles after some consideration. Initially we figured let's go with just one bottle in case a country doesn't have LPG/Autogas gas stations, but we dismissed the thought after checking all the countries we want to travel to.

findingStations.title: Finding gas stations that sell LPG/Autogas
findingStations.paragraph: Initially it was a bit tricky to find gas stations with our usual map and navigation applications until we found <link>myLPG.eu</link>. It's a well maintained app that shows LPG/Autogas gas stations across Europe - exactly what we needed. We can highly recommend this app!

wilmaToilet.title: Toilet
wilmaToilet.heroImageAlt: Image of cow standing in a field during sunset in Oostende, Belgium

bioTioo.title: BioTioo
bioTioo.paragraph1: We decided to get rid of the chemical toilette pretty much from the beginning. Why? We do not want to use any chemicals and try to only use natural things. In addition the chemical toilette is a huge issue if you want to be independent. It can only be emptied as special locations and causes real problems if it is full at the wrong moment.
bioTioo.paragraph2: So, we removed the checmical toilette and replaced it with a dry composting toilet. After thorough research we decided for <link>BioTioo (formerly known as BioToi)</link>, because you do not need to add anything after each visit to the toilette. It has a very handy stirring mechanism that mixes fecal matter with the coconut fibres.
bioTioo.paragraph3: It also has a ventilator which we will install a little later.

wilmaInternet.title: Internet
wilmaInternet.heroImageAlt: Image of snow capped mountains in the Allg√§u region in Germany

background.title: Background
background.paragraph1: There are probably countless videos and articles on the internet about getting access to the internet while travelling with a van/campervan/motorhome. We watched some of those and came to the conclusion there is not "best" solution. Most end in the "recommendation" to have both a cellular antenna and router as well as Starlink if you truly want coverage and connectivity anywhere*.
background.paragraph2: Initially we thought "that's overkill" and decided to go with just Starlink. It worked pretty well and we generally have few complaints. However, just 1 month in Starlink upped their prices (to 72‚Ç¨/month at the time of writing this article) and we overlooked one very important factor:
background.paragraph3: Starlink needs an unobstructed view especially for our use case which is a lot of video calls. You can get away with obstructions for uploads, streaming and surfing no problem. But if you do a lot of video calls then any obstruction will make you very unhappy.
background.paragraph4: Since we don't always want to stay in the middle of a random field to have an unobstructed view, but we also want to be able to stay in say a a forest area, we decided to beef up our internet setup and add a 5G router as well as a 5G antenna.

setup.title: Our setup
list: Starlink V4/3rd Gen (i.e. the "big dish" without self-adjustment and the standard RJ45 connections).
An external RJ45 outlet (professionally installed for free)

wiring.title: Wiring schematics
wiring.paragraph1: The battery delivers 12V to the router as well as the inverter which steps it up to 48V (Starlink requires this voltage). The POE injector adds the power to the ethernet connection going to the Starlink dish. This generation of dish uses a standard RJ45 connector. The LAN port of the POE injector delivers the internet signal via ethernet to the WAN port on the 5G router. Since the modem is built into the dish there is very little configuration required to make this work.
wiring.paragraph2: The 5G router is connected to a 5G antenna mounted to the roof of our van. It can hold up to 2 SIMs and you can seamlessly switch between Starlink or cellular internet.
wiring.paragraph3: The two power switches control Starlink and the router independently. When we use Starlink we do need both, however, when we run on cellular we can switch Starlink off and save a lot of power.

toolboard.title: Toolboard
toolboard.paragraph1: We wanted to have a way to secure our sandboards to the exteriour of the vehicle. These boards will (hopefully) be used seldom and when they're used they will be super dirty afterwards.
toolboard.paragraph2: So, we looked around for a screw-frew solution and found the toolboard from STYYL. It uses the existing heads on the roof of the car and very strong magnets.

wilmaElectricity.title: Electricity
wilmaElectricity.heroImageAlt: Image of our new battery a BullTron 540Ah connected to our campervan Wilma

battery.title: Battery
battery.paragraph: BullTron 540Ah 12.8V Polar (6912Wh) capable of sustaining a load of 150A and 300A peak.

charging.title: Charging
charging.paragraph1: When connected to shore power the battery is charged by the EBL (18A) in parallel to a Victron Energy Blue Smart IP22 Charger delivering 30A.
charging.paragraph2: When driving the EBL delivers 18A in addition to the Victron Energy Orion XS 12/12-50A DC-DC battery charger adding another 50A on top.
charging.paragraph3: When harvesting the sun, we are using a Wattstunde WS340SF+ foldable solar panel delivering 340Wp controlled by a Victron Energy BlueSolar MPPT 100/30 30A solar charge controller.

section3.itemA:
a) Visiting the Website
When you access our website, the browser used on your device automatically sends information to the server of our website. This information is temporarily stored in a so-called log file. The following information is collected without your intervention and stored until it is automatically deleted:
‚Ä¢ IP address of the requesting computer
‚Ä¢ Date and time of access
‚Ä¢ Name and URL of the retrieved file
‚Ä¢ Website from which the access occurred (referrer URL)
‚Ä¢ Browser used, and, if applicable, the operating system of your computer, as well as the name of your access provider.
The data mentioned is processed by us for the following purposes:
‚Ä¢ Ensuring a smooth connection to the website
‚Ä¢ Ensuring convenient use of our website
‚Ä¢ Evaluating system security and stability, and
‚Ä¢ For further administrative purposes.
The legal basis for data processing is Article 6(1)(f) GDPR. Our legitimate interest follows from the purposes for data collection listed above.
section3.itemB:
b) Google Fonts
Our website uses Google Fonts, a service by Google LLC, to ensure uniform font display. When accessing a page, your browser loads the required fonts from Google's servers into its cache. During this process, data such as your IP address and the requested URL are transmitted to Google. This is based on Article 6(1)(f) GDPR, with our legitimate interest being the appealing design of our website. For more information, visit: https://developers.google.com/fonts/faq.
section3.itemC:
c) Amazon Affiliate Links
We participate in the Amazon EU affiliate program. Links to Amazon are embedded on our site, through which we can earn commissions. Amazon uses cookies to trace the origin of orders. This allows Amazon to recognize that you clicked the affiliate link on our website. The storage of Amazon cookies is based on Article 6(1)(f) GDPR. Our legitimate interest lies in correctly accounting for affiliate earnings. For more information, visit https://www.amazon.de/gp/help/customer/display.html?nodeId=201909010.
section3.itemD:
d) Contact Form
When you submit inquiries via our website's contact form, your information, including contact details (e.g., name, email address, message), is stored to process your inquiry and for potential follow-up questions. The data is forwarded via email to our address hosted on Apple's iCloud service and processed there.
Data processing is based on your consent (Article 6(1)(a) GDPR). You can revoke your consent at any time by informal email notification. The legality of data processing until revocation remains unaffected.
section3.itemE:
e) Note on Data Transfer to the USA and Other Third Countries
We use tools from companies based in the USA or other non-secure third countries regarding data protection. These tools may transfer your data to such countries for processing. Please note that the level of data protection in these countries may not be equivalent to the EU standard. For example, U.S. authorities may access your data without judicial recourse.
section3.itemF:
f) SSL or TLS Encryption
For security purposes and to protect the transmission of sensitive information (e.g., inquiries or orders), this website uses SSL or TLS encryption. You can recognize encrypted connections by the change in the browser's address bar from "http://" to "https://" and by the lock icon. Encrypted data cannot be accessed by third parties.
